facts.text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Mysore High Court. The appellant was prosecuted under s. 167  81  of the Sea Customs Act  No. 8 of 1878  read with s. 9 of the Land Customs Act  No. 19 of 1924 .

anchor.surface_text: The incident out of which the present appeal has arisen took place on November 27, 1960 when Goa was number a part of India but was Portuguese territory. The Deputy Superintendent of Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum received information

facts.text: Deputy Superintendent of Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum received information that contraband goods would be found in the house of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Superintendent of Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum received information that companytraband goods would be found in the house of the appellant. Consequently he raided the house in the companypany of three panchas.

facts.text: A big steel trunk, a cane-box and another steel trunk were taken down from the loft in the kitchen.

anchor.surface_text: After necessary formalities the house was searched and a big steel trunk, a cane-box and another steel trunk were taken down from the loft in the kitchen. On opening, a belt, with four pouches stitched to it, was found

facts.text: A belt with four pouches stitched to it was found in the big steel trunk. Inside the pouches, four gold bars with foreign marks and labels of Goa Customs authorities were found.

facts.text: Besides the gold bars, a large sum of money and three small cut pieces of gold were also found in the box.

facts.text: The weight of the gold bars was 343 tolas.

anchor.surface_text: The weight of the gold bars was 343 tolas. On November 30, 1960, the appellant was arrested and inter- rogated by the Deputy Superintendent of Customs and Excise.

facts.text: On November 30, 1960, the appellant was arrested and interrogated by the Deputy Superintendent of Customs and Excise.

facts.text: The appellant admitted that the four gold bars had been given to him on November 27, 1960 in the morning by one Vittal Morajkar of Goa so that he might deliver them back to Morajkar on the motor-stand at Belgaum or near there, and he had kept them in his house.

anchor.surface_text: During this interrogation, the appellant admitted that the four gold bars had been given to him on November 27, 1960 in the moming by one Vittal Morajkar of Goa so that he might deliver them back to Morajkar

facts.text: The appellant was prosecuted on a complaint filed by the Assistant Collector of Central Excise and Land Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was prosecuted on a companyplaint filed by the Assistant Collector of Central Excise and Land Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum. The Magistrate companyvicted the appellant and sentenced him

facts.text: The Magistrate convicted the appellant and sentenced him to imprisonment and fine and also ordered confiscation of the four gold bars.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate companyvicted the appellant and sentenced him to imprisonment and fine and also ordered companyfiscation of the four gold bars. On appeal to the Sessions Judge, the appellant was acquitted

facts.text: On appeal to the Sessions Judge, the appellant was acquitted relying on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Sitaram Agarwala v. State.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Sessions Judge, the appellant was acquitted relying on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Sitaram Agarwala v. State 1 . Then followed an appeal by the State to the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court set aside the acquittal of the appellant and restored the order of conviction and sentence passed by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then ,considered the evidence and relying on the statement made by the appellant to the Deputy Superintendent of Customs and Excise and also on the other evidence produced in the case held that the appellant was guilty.

facts.text: The High Court granted certificate to appeal to this Court as two questions of law of general importance arose.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to -the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court, and as two questions of law of general importance arose in this case, the High Court granted the certificate.

precedents.cited_proposition: an excise officer under the Bihar and Orissa Excise Act is a police officer within the meaning of s. 25 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The leading case in support of this view is Nanoo, Sheikh Ahmed v. Emperor 3 . The other view which may be called the narrow view is that the words police officer in s. 25 of the Evidence Act mean a police officer properly so-called and do number include officers of other departments of government who may be charged with the duty to investigate under special Acts special crimes thereunder like excise offences or customs offences, and so on.

precedents.cited_proposition: broad construction of 'police officer' in s. 25 Evidence Act to include officers with powers of investigation of offences

anchor.surface_text: The leading case in support of this view is Radha Kishun Marwari King-Emperor 4 . The other High Courts have followed one view or the other, the majority being in favour of the view taken by the Bombay High Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: narrow construction of 'police officer' in s. 25 Evidence Act to mean only police officers properly so-called, excluding other departmental officers
